def: Formal notice giving 14 days to fix a breach.
Rents a room with meals (homestay style); often not covered by tenancy law.
Property with 6+ tenants sharing facilities under separate tenancy agreements.
Security deposit (up to 4 weeks’ rent) lodged with Tenancy Services.
When a party fails to meet obligations under the tenancy agreement.
"Bring Your Own" (often drinks/food at flat dinners or parties).
Movable items that come with the tenancy (e.g., fridge, washing machine).
Weekly schedule of cleaning responsibilities shared among flatmates.
Checklist describing the property at move‑in; used at move‑out to compare.
For disputes between flatmates (not matters under tenancy law).
Colloquial for someone who never does dishes — don’t be one!
Being required to leave the property; must follow legal steps.
Normal aging (e.g., carpet flattening) — not the same as damage (e.g., stains).
Runs for a set time (e.g., 12 months); leaving early needs agreement.
Shared costs like power, internet, or cleaning products.
Agreement between flatmates covering bills, cleaning, etc. (separate from the tenancy agreement).
Someone who shares the house with you; own room, shared facilities.
Separate agreement between tenants/flatmates; not covered by the RTA.
Sharing a house or apartment with others (flatmates). Common in NZ.
A person who agrees to pay rent/debt if the tenant cannot.
NZ minimum standards for heating, insulation, ventilation, moisture and drainage.
Tenant on the lease who may sublet rooms and is responsible to the landlord.
Information the landlord provides about insulation in ceilings/floors/walls.
Any extra payment demanded to secure a tenancy outside of rent/bond.
Person or company that owns the property and rents it out (incl. property managers).
Proof the bond has been lodged with Tenancy Services (landlord must not hold it).
Discount given to friends, sometimes used for rent or selling things.
Common in damp conditions; manage with ventilation and dehumidifiers.
Written heads‑up that you’re moving out or ending the tenancy; must follow time rules.
Required time to warn the other party before ending a tenancy or raising rent.
Ongoing agreement with no end date; ends when proper notice is given.
Tenant’s right to reasonable peace, privacy, and comfort in their home.
Overdue/unpaid rent.
Rent paid before the period of occupancy (commonly 1–2 weeks in NZ).
Landlord inspection for tidiness/damage; at least 48 hours’ notice required.
Slang for dirty/gross.
Renting out your room/flat to someone else; usually needs landlord consent.
Short for “sort out” or “figure out” (e.g., “Let’s suss the bills”).
Contract between landlord and tenant setting out the terms of the tenancy.
NZ body that resolves tenancy disputes between tenants and landlords.
Person who signs the tenancy agreement; covered by the Residential Tenancies Act.
Landlord entering without proper notice (except in emergencies).
Electricity, gas, water, internet; may be split among flatmates.
Scheduled times to inspect a property before applying.
